ditems.name: Motivation
ditems.description: Motivation is a theoretical construct used to explain behavior. It represents the reasons for people's actions, desires, and needs.

ditems.name: Engagement
ditems.description: In education, student engagement refers to the degree of attention, curiosity, interest, optimism, and passion that students show when they are learning or being taught, which extends to the level of motivation they have to learn and progress in their education

ditems.name: Social Learning
ditems.description: Social Learning that takes place at a wider scale than individual or group learning, up to a societal scale, through social interaction between peers.

ditems.name: Assessment
ditems.description: Learning takes place in students' heads where it is invisible to others. This means that learning must assessed through performance: what students can do with their learning.

ditems.name: Recommendation
ditems.description: Recommendation or feedback is information about how we are doing in our efforts to reach a goal

ditems.name: Self-reflection
ditems.description: Human self-reflection is the capacity of humans to exercise introspection and the willingness to learn more about their fundamental nature, purpose and essence.

ditems.name: Goal-Setting
ditems.description: Goal setting involves the development of an action plan designated to motivate and guide a person or group toward a goal.

ditems.name: Awareness
ditems.description: Awareness is the ability to perceive, to feel, or to conscious of events, objects, thoughts, emotions, or sensory patterns.

ditems.name: Self-confidence
ditems.description: The socio-psychological concept of self-confidence relates to self-assurance in one's personal judgment, ability, power, etc.
